awd_titl_txt: Ethnic Movement, Economy, and Incorporation in a Border Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the conditions of migration, settlement, and incorporation of people who moved to a bi-national border region from a third country. The international expansion of multi-national corporations and bi-national economic border operations has facilitated the increase in people who are from neither border country but have transborder lives. This project examines how the unidirectional movement of people and capital investment contributes to regional border economies, and how community economic networks shape settlement processes in the border region. The study also will evaluate how people that are engaged in inter-community social and economic interactions within both countries are integrated into them, and how community ties, identity, and political context affect their integration process. The findings will inform bi-national economic community stakeholders, local government officials and policymakers, and community leaders on issues of regional development and strategies for balanced accommodation and integration of a fast-growing population.    

The project involves an intensive case study of border communities that engage in transborder economic activities. The main objective of the project is to understand the political and economic contexts of their migration and settlement processes and to identify the factors that affect their incorporation processes. Data come from: (1) interviews with three groups of border residents from the community, namely, business operators on either side of the border and commuters; (2) field observations at community churches, businesses, and community events related to the regional economy; and (3) archival research of local and community periodicals related to the regional economy. The project will provide important insights into the impact of contemporary economic trade and transnational investment on international migration and how bi-national economic settings influence people?s inter-community relations and incorporation processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates the conditions of migration, settlement, and incorporation of immigrants who moved to a binational border region from a third country. More specifically the project examines the formation of Korean immigrant communities in the U.S.-Mexico border region. The study allows a closer look at how the expansion of multinational corporations has facilitated the development of ethnic immigrant community in the region, and how the presence of multinational corporations foster ethnic entrepreneurship and transborder ethnic economy. In this context, findings point to how immigrant incorporation process is stratified based on individual attributes and social and professional networks.

Immigrants’ co-ethnic relations are complex: co-ethnic economy can provide a haven or gateway for those who are excluded from the mainstream labor market, while anomie, tension, conflicts exist within co-ethnic community as well. This study extends the current understanding of co-ethnic relations by examining social and economic stratification among ethnic communities. The study reveals various hierarchical relations within co-ethnic communities stemming from business relations, socioeconomic background, and positions at workplace and they are contributing factors to social stratification among the co-ethnics. Further, the study’s findings will be relevant to various subfields of sociology, for example, highly skilled migration, political sociology, transborder ethnic economy, gender and family migration, and Asian-Latino interracial relations.

The project has provided valuable resources in conducting this ethnographic research and created vital educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students through research assistantships. In addition to a book chapter published on the topic, I have submitted and will submit multiple manuscripts for publication about the studied community. The project has drawn interests from both the public and academic in the United States and Mexico. The study will have generated related questions about Asian immigrants in the US-Mexico border region.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Minjeong Kim
